If you or someone you know is thinking about suicide, call or text 988 or chat 988lifeline.org. You can also call 1-800-273-8255 (1-800-273-TALK). The 988 Suicide and Crisis Lifeline provides free and confidential support 24/7, anytime day or night.

You can also call 911 or the local emergency number or go to the hospital emergency room. DO NOT delay.

If someone you know has attempted suicide, call 911 or the local emergency number right away. DO NOT leave the person alone, even after you have called for help.

---

**Generalized Anxiety Disorder - Self-Care**

**Managing Symptoms**

When symptoms occur, it's essential to learn how to **stress and relax**. Avoid thinking that minor problems will develop into terrible ones.

**Talk Therapy**

Other types of talk therapy may also be helpful in managing symptoms of an anxiety disorder. Your provider can discuss talk therapy options with you, and then you can decide together if it's right for you.

**Therapy**

*   Talk therapy takes place with a trained therapist.
*   It helps you learn ways of managing and reducing your anxiety.
*   Some forms of talk therapy can help you understand what causes your anxiety, allowing you to gain better control over it.

**Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT)**

Many types of talk therapy may be helpful for GAD. One common and effective talk therapy is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT). CBT can help you understand the relationship between your thoughts, behaviors, and symptoms. Often, CBT involves a set number of visits.

During CBT, you can learn how to:

*   Understand and gain control of distorted views of stressors.
*   Recognize and replace panic-causing thoughts to help you feel more in control.
*   Manage stress and relax when symptoms occur.
*   Avoid thinking that minor problems will develop into terrible ones.

**Other Ways to Manage Your Anxiety**

Taking medicine and going to talk therapy can get you started on the road to feeling better. Taking care of your body and relationships can help improve your condition. Here are some helpful tips:

*   Get enough sleep.
*   Eat healthy foods.
*   Keep a regular daily schedule.
*   Get out of the house every day.
*   Exercise every day, even if it's just a 15-minute walk.
*   Stay away from alcohol and street drugs.
*   Talk with family or friends when you feel nervous or frightened.
*   Find out about different types of group activities you can join.

**When to Call the Doctor**

Call your provider if you:

*   Find it hard to control your anxiety
*   Do not sleep well
*   Feel sad or feel like you want to hurt yourself
*   Have physical symptoms from your anxiety

If you or someone you know is thinking about suicide, call or text 988 or chat 988lifeline.org. You can also call 1-800-273-8255 (1-800-273-TALK). The 988 Suicide and Crisis Lifeline provides free and confidential support 24/7, anytime day or night.

You can also call 911 or the local emergency number or go to the hospital emergency room. DO NOT delay.

If someone you know has attempted suicide, call 911 or the local emergency number right away. DO NOT leave the person alone, even after you have called for help.

---

**Generalized Anxiety Disorder - Self-Care**

\n\n**What is Generalized Anxiety Disorder?**

According to the American Psychiatric Association, generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) is a type of anxiety disorder characterized by excessive worry about everyday things, even when there's no apparent reason to worry. This worry can be persistent and interfere with daily life.

\n\n**Causes and Risk Factors**

Research suggests that GAD may be caused by a combination of genetic, environmental, and psychological factors. Some studies have found that people with a family history of anxiety disorders are more likely to develop GAD. Additionally, certain personality traits, such as perfectionism or low self-esteem, may increase the risk of developing GAD.

\n\n**Symptoms**

The symptoms of GAD can vary from person to person, but common experiences include:

*   Excessive worry about everyday things
*   Difficulty controlling worries
*   Restlessness or feeling on edge
*   Difficulty concentrating
*   Irritability
*   Sleep disturbances

\n\n**Treatment Options**

Treatment for GAD typically involves a combination of self-help strategies and professional therapy. Some effective treatments include:

*   Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT)
*   Medications, such as antidepressants or anti-anxiety drugs
*   Relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation
*   Exercise and physical activity

\n\n**Self-Care Strategies**

In addition to professional treatment, there are several self-care strategies that can help manage GAD symptoms. These include:

*   Keeping a worry journal to track and challenge negative thoughts
*   Engaging in regular exercise and physical activity
*   Practicing relaxation techniques, such as meditation or yoga
*   Setting realistic goals and breaking tasks into smaller, manageable steps

\n\n**Resources**

For more information on GAD and self-care strategies, consider consulting the following resources:

*   American Psychiatric Association: Anxiety Disorders - What Are Anxiety Disorders?
*   Barnhill JW, Jongerden L, Bogels S, et al. Anxiety disorders American Psychiatric Association. In: Barnhill JW, ed. Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders. 5th ed, Text Revision (DSM-5-TR). Arlington, VA: American Psychiatric Publishing; 2022:chap 5.
*   Lee RA. Anxiety. In: Rakel D, Minichiello VJ, eds. Integrative Medicine. 5th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2023:chap 7.

\n\n**Review Date**

This article was last reviewed on May 10, 2023, by Fred K. Berger, MD, addiction and forensic psychiatrist, Scripps Memorial Hospital, La Jolla, CA. Also reviewed by David C. Dugdale, MD, Medical Director, Brenda Conaway, Editorial Director, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.

title: Generalized anxiety disorder in children: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Generalized Anxiety Disorder in Children**

**What is Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD)?**

Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) is a mental disorder in which a child is often worried or anxious about many things and finds it hard to control this anxiety.

**Causes of GAD**

The cause of GAD is unknown. Genes may play a role. Children with family members who have an anxiety disorder also may be more likely to have one. Stress may be a factor in developing GAD.

Things in a child's life that can cause stress and anxiety include:

*   Loss, such as death of a loved one or parents' divorce
*   Big life changes, such as moving to a new town
*   A history of abuse
*   Living with family with members who are fearful, anxious, or violent

**Symptoms of GAD**

The main symptom is frequent worry or tension for at least 6 months, even with little or no clear cause. Worries seem to float from one problem to another. Children with anxiety commonly focus their worries on:

*   Doing well at school and sports. They may have the feeling that they need to perform perfectly or otherwise feel they are not doing well.
*   The safety of themselves or their family. They may feel intense fear of natural calamities such as earthquakes, tornados, or home break-ins.
*   Illness in themselves or their family. They may worry excessively over minor illnesses they have or be fearful of developing new illnesses.

Even when the child is aware that worries or fears are excessive, a child with GAD still has difficulty controlling them. The child often needs reassurance.

Other symptoms of GAD include:

*   Problems concentrating, or the mind going blank
*   Fatigue
*   Irritability
*   Problems falling or staying asleep, or sleep that is restless and unsatisfying
*   Restlessness when awake
*   Not eating enough or overeating
*   Outbursts of anger
*   A pattern of being disobedient, hostile, and defiant

Expecting the worst, even when there is no apparent reason for concern.

Your child may also have other physical symptoms such as:

*   Muscle tension
*   Upset stomach
*   Sweating
*   Difficulty breathing
*   Headaches

---

**Generalized Anxiety Disorder in Children**

**Causes**

The cause of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) is unknown, but genes may play a role. Children with family members who have an anxiety disorder are more likely to develop one. Stress can also be a factor in developing GAD.

*   Loss, such as death of a loved one or parents' divorce
*   Big life changes, such as moving to a new town
*   A history of abuse
*   Living with family members who are fearful, anxious, or violent

GAD is a common condition, affecting about 2% to 6% of children. It usually does not occur until puberty and is more often seen in girls than in boys.

**Symptoms**

The main symptom of GAD is frequent worry or tension for at least 6 months, even with little or no clear cause. Worries seem to float from one problem to another. Children with anxiety commonly focus their worries on:

*   Doing well at school and sports
*   The safety of themselves or their family
*   Illness in themselves or their family

Even when the child is aware that worries or fears are excessive, a child with GAD still has difficulty controlling them. The child often needs reassurance.

Other symptoms of GAD include:

*   Problems concentrating or the mind going blank
*   Fatigue
*   Irritability
*   Problems falling or staying asleep, or sleep that is restless and unsatisfying
*   Restlessness when awake
*   Not eating enough or overeating
*   Outbursts of anger
*   A pattern of being disobedient, hostile, and defiant

**Expecting the Worst**

Children with GAD often expect the worst, even when there is no apparent reason for concern.

**Physical Symptoms**

Your child may also have other physical symptoms such as:

*   Muscle tension
*   Upset stomach
*   Sweating
*   Difficulty breathing
*   Headaches

Anxiety symptoms can affect a child's daily life, making it hard for the child to sleep, eat, and perform well in school.

---

**Generalized Anxiety Disorder in Children**

**What is Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD)?**

Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) is a type of anxiety disorder that affects children. It is characterized by excessive worry or fear about various things, such as school performance, health, relationships, or other issues.

**Symptoms of GAD in Children**

* Excessive worry or fear about various things
* Difficulty controlling worries or fears
* Problems concentrating or paying attention
* Fatigue
* Irritability
* Restlessness when awake
* Not eating enough or overeating
* Outbursts of anger
* Disobedient, hostile, and defiant behavior

**Physical Symptoms of GAD in Children**

* Muscle tension
* Upset stomach
* Sweating
* Difficulty breathing
* Headaches

**Impact on Daily Life**

Anxiety symptoms can affect a child's daily life, making it hard for them to sleep, eat, and perform well in school.

**Diagnosis**

GAD is diagnosed based on your and your child's answers to questions about their symptoms. A physical exam or lab tests may be done to check for other conditions that can cause similar symptoms.

**Treatment**

The goal of treatment is to help your child feel better and function well in daily life. In less severe cases, talk therapy or medicine alone can be helpful. In more severe cases, a combination of these may work best.

* **Talk Therapy**: Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) can help your child understand the relationship between their thoughts, behaviors, and symptoms.
* **Medicines**: Antidepressants and sedatives may be used to help control anxiety in children.

**Outlook (Prognosis)**

How well a child does depends on how severe the condition is. In some cases, GAD is long-term and is difficult to treat. However, most children get better with medicine, talk therapy, or both.

**Possible Complications**

Having an anxiety disorder can put a child at risk for depression and substance abuse.

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

Contact your child's provider if your child frequently worries or feels anxious, and it interferes with their daily activities.

---

**Generalized Anxiety Disorder in Children**

**What is generalized anxiety disorder?**

Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) is a condition where children feel anxious or worried most of the time, even when there's no apparent reason to be anxious. This anxiety is excessive and interferes with their daily activities.

**Contact your child's provider if:**

* Your child frequently worries or feels anxious
* It interferes with their daily activities

**References:**

* Baker AW, Dekel S, Jagodnik KM, Pace-Schott EF, Post LM, Orr SP. Anxiety disorders and post-traumatic stress disorder. In: Stern TA, Wilens TE, Fava M, eds. Massachusetts General Hospital Comprehensive Clinical Psychiatry. 3rd ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2025:chap 31.
* Kim RK. Anxiety disorders, obsessive-compulsive Disorder, and posttraumatic stress disorder. In: Kliegman RM, St. Geme JW, Blum NJ, et al, eds. Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics. 22nd ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2025:chap 38.
* Thom RP, Prince JB, Rubin DH. Child and adolescent psychiatric disorders. In: Stern TA, Wilens TE, Fava M, eds. Massachusetts General Hospital Comprehensive Clinical Psychiatry. 3rd ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2025:chap 39.

**Review Date:** July 31, 2024

**Updated by:** Charles I. Schwartz, MD, FAAP, and reviewed by David C. Dugdale, MD, Brenda Conaway, Editorial Director, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.

**Related MedlinePlus Health Topics:**

* Anxiety
* Child Mental Health

title: Generalized anxiety disorder: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Generalized Anxiety Disorder**

**What is it?**

Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) is a mental disorder where a person is often worried or anxious about many things and finds it hard to control this anxiety.

**Causes**

The cause of GAD is unknown, but genes may play a role. Stress may also contribute to the development of GAD.

**Who can get it?**

GAD is a common condition that anyone can develop, even children. It occurs more often in women than in men.

**Symptoms**

* Frequent worry or tension for at least 6 months, even when there is little or no clear cause
* Worries often seem to float from one problem to another (e.g., family, relationships, work, school, money, health)
* Difficulty controlling worries or fears, even when aware they are stronger than appropriate for the situation
* Other symptoms:
	+ Problems concentrating
	+ Fatigue
	+ Irritability
	+ Problems falling or staying asleep, or sleep that is restless and unsatisfying
	+ Restlessness when awake
	+ Physical symptoms: muscle tension, upset stomach, sweating, difficulty breathing

**Exams and Tests**

There is no test that can make a diagnosis of GAD. The diagnosis is based on your answers to questions about the symptoms of GAD.

**Treatment**

The goal of treatment is to help you feel better and function well in daily life. Talk therapy or medicine alone can be helpful. Sometimes, a combination of these may work best.

* **Talk Therapy**
	+ Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) can help you understand the relationship between your thoughts, behaviors, and symptoms.
	+ CBT involves learning how to:
		- Understand and gain control of distorted views of stressors
		- Recognize and replace panic-causing thoughts
		- Manage stress and relax when symptoms occur
		- Avoid thinking that minor problems will develop into terrible ones
* **Medicines**
	+ Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs)
	+ Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs)
	+ Other medicines such as hydroxyzine or gabapentin may also be tried

**Self-Care**

In addition to taking medicine and going to therapy, you can help yourself get better by:

* Reducing caffeine intake
* Not using street drugs or large amounts of alcohol
* Exercising, getting enough rest, and eating healthy foods
* Keeping a regular schedule and getting out of the house every day

**Support Groups**

You can ease the stress of having GAD by joining a support group. Sharing with others who have common experiences and problems can help you not feel alone.

**Possible Complications**

Depression and substance abuse may occur with an anxiety disorder.

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

Contact your provider if you frequently worry or feel anxious, especially if it interferes with your daily activities.

---

**Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD)**

**Causes**

*   The cause of GAD is unknown.
*   Genes may play a role.
*   Stress may also contribute to the development of GAD.

**GAD is a common condition. Anyone can develop this disorder, even children. GAD occurs more often in women than in men.**

**Symptoms**

*   The main symptom is frequent worry or tension for at least 6 months, even when there is little or no clear cause.
*   Worries often seem to float from one problem to another. Problems may involve family, other relationships, work, school, money, and health.
*   Even when they are aware that worries or fears are stronger than appropriate for the situation, a person with GAD still has difficulty controlling them.
*   Other symptoms of GAD include:
    *   Problems concentrating
    *   Fatigue
    *   Irritability
    *   Problems falling or staying asleep, or sleep that is restless and unsatisfying
    *   Restlessness when awake
*   The person may also have other physical symptoms. These can include muscle tension, upset stomach, sweating, or difficulty breathing.

**Treatment**

The goal of treatment is to help you feel better and function well in daily life. Talk therapy or medicine alone can be helpful. Sometimes, a combination of these may work best.

*   **TALK THERAPY**
    *   Many types of talk therapy may be helpful for GAD.
    *   One common and effective talk therapy is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT).
    *   CBT can help you understand the relationship between your thoughts, behaviors, and symptoms.
    *   During CBT, you can learn how to:
        1.  Understand and gain control of distorted views of stressors, such as other people's behavior or life events.
        2.  Recognize and replace panic-causing thoughts to help you feel more in control.
        3.  Manage stress and relax when symptoms occur.
        4.  Avoid thinking that minor problems will develop into terrible ones.
*   **MEDICINES**
    *   Certain medicines, often also used to treat depression, may be very helpful for this disorder.
    *   They work by preventing your symptoms or making them less severe.
    *   You must take these medicines every day. DO NOT stop taking them without talking with your provider.
    *   These medicines include:
        1.  Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), which are most often the first choice of antidepressants
        2.  Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), which are another choice
    *   Other medicines such as hydroxyzine or medicines used to treat seizures, like gabapentin, may also be tried.
    *   These medicines act more quickly and may be taken as needed rather than regularly.
*   **SELF-CARE**
    *   Other than taking medicine and going to therapy, you can help yourself get better by:
        1.  Reducing caffeine intake
        2.  Not using street drugs or large amounts of alcohol
        3.  Exercising, getting enough rest, and eating healthy foods
        4.  Keeping a regular schedule and getting out of the house every day

**Possible Complications**

*   Depression and substance abuse may occur with an anxiety disorder.

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

Contact your provider if you frequently worry or feel anxious, especially if it interferes with your daily activities.

---

**Generalized Anxiety Disorder**

**What is Generalized Anxiety Disorder?**

Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) is a type of anxiety disorder characterized by excessive and persistent worry about everyday things, even when there's no apparent reason to worry.

**Symptoms of GAD**

Other symptoms of GAD include:

* The person may also have other physical symptoms. These can include muscle tension, upset stomach, sweating, or difficulty breathing.
* Exams and Tests
There is no test that can make a diagnosis of GAD. The diagnosis is based on your answers to questions about the symptoms of GAD. Your health care provider will ask about these symptoms. You will also be asked about other aspects of your mental and physical health. A physical exam or lab tests may be done to check for other conditions that cause similar symptoms.

**Treatment**

The goal of treatment is to help you feel better and function well in daily life. Talk therapy or medicine alone can be helpful. Sometimes, a combination of these may work best.

**Talk Therapy**

Many types of talk therapy may be helpful for GAD. One common and effective talk therapy is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT). CBT can help you understand the relationship between your thoughts, behaviors, and symptoms. Often CBT involves a set number of visits. During CBT you can learn how to:

* Understand and gain control of distorted views of stressors, such as other people's behavior or life events.
* Recognize and replace panic-causing thoughts to help you feel more in control.
* Manage stress and relax when symptoms occur.
* Avoid thinking that minor problems will develop into terrible ones.

**Medicines**

Certain medicines, often also used to treat depression, may be very helpful for this disorder. They work by preventing your symptoms or making them less severe. You must take these medicines every day. DO NOT stop taking them without talking with your provider. They include:

* Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), which are most often the first choice of antidepressants
* Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), which are another choice

**Self-Care**

Other than taking medicine and going to therapy, you can help yourself get better by:

* Reducing caffeine intake
* Not using street drugs or large amounts of alcohol
* Exercising, getting enough rest, and eating healthy foods
* Keeping a regular schedule and getting out of the house every day

**Support Groups**

You can ease the stress of having GAD by joining a support group. Sharing with others who have common experiences and problems can help you not feel alone. Support groups are usually not a good substitute for talk therapy or taking medicine, but can be a helpful addition.

---

**Generalized Anxiety Disorder**

**What is Generalized Anxiety Disorder?**

Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) is a type of anxiety disorder characterized by excessive and persistent worry about everyday things, even when there is no apparent reason to worry.

**Symptoms**

* Persistent and excessive worry about everyday things
* Difficulty controlling worry
* Restlessness or feeling on edge
* Difficulty concentrating
* Irritability
* Muscle tension

**Causes**

The exact causes of GAD are not fully understood, but it is thought to be related to a combination of genetic, environmental, and psychological factors.

**Diagnosis**

GAD can be diagnosed by a mental health professional using the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5).

**Treatment**

Treatment for GAD typically involves a combination of psychotherapy and medication. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) has been shown to be effective in reducing symptoms of GAD.

**Support Groups**

Joining a support group can help ease the stress of having GAD by sharing with others who have common experiences and problems.

**Outlook (Prognosis)**

How well a person does depends on how severe the condition is. In some cases, GAD is long-term and is difficult to treat. Most people get better with medicine or talk therapy.

**Possible Complications**

Depression and substance abuse may occur with an anxiety disorder.

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

Contact your provider if you frequently worry or feel anxious, especially if it interferes with your daily activities.

**Alternative Names**

GAD; Anxiety disorder

**References**

* American Psychiatric Association. Anxiety disorders. Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders. 5th ed. Text Revision (DSM-5-TR). Arlington, VA: American Psychiatric Publishing; 2022:chap 5.
* Calkins AW, Bui E, Taylor CT, Pollack MH, LeBeau RT, Simon NM. Anxiety disorders. In: Stern TA, Fava M, Wilens TE, Rosenbaum JF, eds. Massachusetts General Hospital Comprehensive Clinical Psychiatry. 2nd ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2016:chap 32.
* Lyness JM. Psychiatric disorders in medical practice. In: Goldman L, Schafer AI, eds. Goldman-Cecil Medicine. 26th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2020:chap 369.

**Test Your Knowledge**

Test your knowledge about GAD by taking a short quiz.

title: Generalized arterial calcification of infancy: MedlinePlus Genetics
content:
**Generalized Arterial Calcification of Infancy**

**Description**

Generalized arterial calcification of infancy (GACI) is a disorder affecting the circulatory system that becomes apparent before birth or within the first few months of life. It is characterized by abnormal accumulation of the mineral calcium (calcification) in the walls of the blood vessels that carry blood from the heart to the rest of the body (the arteries). This calcification often occurs along with thickening of the lining of the arterial walls (the intima).

These changes lead to narrowing (stenosis) and stiffness of the arteries, which forces the heart to work harder to pump blood. As a result, heart failure may develop in affected individuals, with signs and symptoms including:

* Difficulty breathing
* Accumulation of fluid (edema) in the extremities
* Bluish appearance of the skin or lips (cyanosis)
* Severe high blood pressure (hypertension)
* Enlarged heart (cardiomegaly)

People with GACI may also have calcification in other organs and tissues, particularly around the joints. In addition, they may have hearing loss or softening and weakening of the bones (rickets).

**Similarities to Pseudoxanthoma Elasticum**

Some individuals with GACI also develop features similar to those of another disorder called pseudoxanthoma elasticum (PXE). PXE is characterized by the accumulation of calcium and other minerals (mineralization) in elastic fibers, which are a component of connective tissue. Connective tissue provides strength and flexibility to structures throughout the body.

Features characteristic of PXE that also occur in GACI include:

* Yellowish bumps called papules on the underarms and other areas of skin that touch when a joint bends (flexor areas)
* Abnormalities called angioid streaks affecting tissue at the back of the eye, which can be detected during an eye examination

**Prognosis**

As a result of the cardiovascular problems associated with GACI, individuals with this condition often do not survive past infancy, with death typically caused by a heart attack or stroke. However, affected individuals who survive their first six months, known as the critical period, can live into adolescence or early adulthood.

---

**Generalized Arterial Calcification of Infancy**

**What is Generalized Arterial Calcification of Infancy?**

Generalized arterial calcification of infancy (GACI) is a rare genetic disorder that affects the circulatory system. It becomes apparent before birth or within the first few months of life and is characterized by abnormal accumulation of calcium in the walls of the blood vessels.

**Symptoms and Features**

People with GACI may experience:

*   Calcification in other organs and tissues, particularly around the joints
*   Hearing loss or softening and weakening of the bones (rickets)
*   Yellowish bumps called papules on the underarms and other areas of skin that touch when a joint bends (flexor areas)
*   Abnormalities called angioid streaks affecting tissue at the back of the eye

**Causes**

GACI is caused by mutations in the ENPP1 gene, which provides instructions for making a protein that helps break down extracellular ATP. Mutations in this gene result in reduced availability of pyrophosphate, leading to excessive calcification in the body.

In some cases, GACI can also be caused by mutations in the ABCC6 gene, which provides instructions for making a protein called MRP6. This protein is thought to transport certain substances across the cell membrane and stimulate the release of ATP from cells.

**Prevalence**

The prevalence of GACI has been estimated to be about 1 in 391,000. At least 200 affected individuals have been described in the medical literature.

**Prognosis**

As a result of the cardiovascular problems associated with GACI, individuals with this condition often do not survive past infancy, with death typically caused by a heart attack or stroke. However, affected individuals who survive their first six months can live into adolescence or early adulthood.

---

**Generalized Arterial Calcification of Infancy**

**Causes of the Disorder**

In about two-thirds of cases, Generalized Arterial Calcification of Infancy (GACI) is caused by mutations in the ENPP1 gene. This gene provides instructions for making a protein that helps break down a molecule called adenosine triphosphate (ATP), specifically when it is found outside the cell (extracellular). Extracellular ATP is quickly broken down into other molecules called adenosine monophosphate (AMP) and pyrophosphate. Pyrophosphate is important in controlling calcification and other mineralization in the body.

Mutations in the ENPP1 gene are thought to result in reduced availability of pyrophosphate, leading to excessive calcification in the body and causing the signs and symptoms of GACI.

GACI can also be caused by mutations in the ABCC6 gene. This gene provides instructions for making a protein called MRP6, also known as the ABCC6 protein. This protein is found primarily in the liver and kidneys, with small amounts in other tissues such as the skin, stomach, blood vessels, and eyes.

MRP6 is thought to transport certain substances across the cell membrane; however, the substances have not been identified. Some studies suggest that the MRP6 protein stimulates the release of ATP from cells through an unknown mechanism, allowing it to be broken down into AMP and pyrophosphate and helping to control deposition of calcium and other minerals in the body.

Other studies suggest that a substance transported by MRP6 is involved in the breakdown of ATP. This unidentified substance is thought to help prevent mineralization of tissues.

Mutations in the ABCC6 gene lead to an absent or nonfunctional MRP6 protein. It is unclear how a lack of properly functioning MRP6 protein leads to GACI. This shortage may impair the release of ATP from cells. As a result, little pyrophosphate is produced, and calcium accumulates in the blood vessels and other tissues affected by GACI.

Alternatively, a lack of functioning MRP6 may impair the transport of a substance that would normally prevent mineralization, leading to the abnormal accumulation of calcium characteristic of GACI.

**Unknown Cause**

Some people with GACI do not have mutations in the ENPP1 or ABCC6 gene. In these affected individuals, the cause of the disorder is unknown.

---

**Generalized Arterial Calcification of Infancy**

**What is Generalized Arterial Calcification of Infancy?**

Generalized arterial calcification of infancy (GACI) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the accumulation of calcium in the arteries, leading to hardening and narrowing of the blood vessels. This condition typically affects infants and can be fatal if left untreated.

**Causes and Risk Factors**

GACI is caused by mutations in either the ENPP1 or ABCC6 genes. These mutations affect the body's ability to regulate calcium levels, leading to excessive calcification of the arteries.

**Symptoms**

The symptoms of GACI may include:

*   Hardening and narrowing of the blood vessels
*   High blood pressure
*   Shortness of breath
*   Fatigue
*   Poor appetite

**Diagnosis**

Diagnosing GACI typically involves a combination of genetic testing, imaging studies (such as ultrasound or X-rays), and laboratory tests to measure calcium levels in the blood.

**Treatment and Management**

There is no cure for GACI, but treatment may focus on managing symptoms and preventing complications. This may include:

*   Medications to lower blood pressure and reduce inflammation
*   Lifestyle changes, such as a balanced diet and regular exercise
*   Close monitoring of calcium levels and blood vessel function

**Prognosis**

The prognosis for GACI is generally poor, with most infants not surviving beyond infancy. However, some cases may be identified through prenatal testing or in utero diagnosis, allowing for early intervention and potentially improved outcomes.

**Genetic Considerations**

GACI is a genetic disorder that can be inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. This means that both parents must carry the mutated gene for their child to be affected. Understanding the genetic basis of GACI can help families make informed decisions about prenatal testing and reproductive planning.

---

**Generalized Arterial Calcification of Infancy**

**Understanding Genetics**

*   **What is the prognosis of a genetic condition?**
*   **How can gene variants affect health and development?**
*   **What does it mean if a disorder seems to run in my family?**
*   **What are the different ways a genetic condition can be inherited?**
*   **How are genetic conditions treated or managed?**

**Related Health Topics**

*   Genetic Disorders
*   Vascular Diseases

**Medical Encyclopedia**

*   **Calcification**: A process where calcium deposits form in various tissues, leading to hardening and rigidity.
*   **Genetics**: The study of heredity and variation in living organisms.
*   **Rickets**: A disease caused by vitamin D deficiency, leading to softening of bones.

**Related Medical Tests**

*   **Calcium Blood Test**: A test used to measure the level of calcium in the blood, helping diagnose conditions like generalized arterial calcification of infancy.

title: Generalized pustular psoriasis: MedlinePlus Genetics
content:
**Generalized Pustular Psoriasis**

**What is Generalized Pustular Psoriasis?**

Generalized pustular psoriasis (GPP) is a severe form of a skin disorder called psoriasis. GPP and other forms of psoriasis are caused by abnormal inflammation. Inflammation is a normal immune system response to injury and foreign invaders (such as bacteria). However, when inflammation is abnormal and uncontrolled, it can damage the body's tissues and organs.

**Symptoms**

Individuals with GPP have repeated episodes in which large areas of skin become red and inflamed and develop small pus-filled blisters (pustules). The skin problems can be accompanied by fever, extreme tiredness (fatigue), muscle weakness, an increased number of white blood cells, and other signs of inflammation throughout the body (systemic inflammation).

**Causes**

Mutations in several genes, including IL36RN and CARD14, increase the risk of developing GPP. These two genes provide instructions for making proteins that play roles in regulating inflammation, particularly in the skin.

**Frequency**

GPP is the rarest form of psoriasis. Although the worldwide prevalence of GPP is unknown, the condition is estimated to affect 2 per million people in Europe. It also occurs in approximately 0.6 per million people each year in Japan.

---

**Generalized Pustular Psoriasis**

**Understanding the Genetics Behind GPP**

GPP is a rare and severe form of psoriasis characterized by widespread pustules on the skin and systemic inflammation. Research has identified several genes associated with an increased risk of developing GPP.

**The Role of IL36RN and CARD14 Genes**

Two key genes, IL36RN and CARD14, play a crucial role in regulating inflammation in the skin. The IL-36Ra protein produced from the IL36RN gene blocks the activity of specific proteins that trigger signaling pathways to promote skin inflammation. Conversely, the CARD14 protein normally turns on inflammation signaling.

**Gene Mutations and GPP Risk**

Mutations in the IL36RN gene are most often associated with GPP alone and are only rarely found in individuals who also have PV. Mutations in this gene appear to be the most common genetic risk factor for GPP alone. CARD14 gene mutations, on the other hand, are more frequently found in individuals with both GPP and PV.

**Inheritance Patterns**

When associated with IL36RN gene mutations, the risk of GPP is typically inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, meaning both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations. When associated with CARD14 gene mutations, GPP risk is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, meaning one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to increase the risk of the disorder.

**Environmental and Other Genetic Factors**

Having a gene mutation in one of the associated genes does not mean an individual will develop GPP. Researchers suspect that environmental or other genetic factors help determine whether an individual will develop the condition.

---

**Generalized Pustular Psoriasis**

**Inheritance Patterns**

When associated with IL36RN gene mutations, risk of GPP is typically inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations. The parents of an individual with an autosomal recessive condition each carry one copy of the mutated gene.

When associated with CARD14 gene mutations, GPP risk is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to increase the risk of the disorder. In some cases, an affected person inherits the mutation from one parent. Other cases result from new (de novo) mutations in the gene.

**Other Names for This Condition**

* Acute generalised pustular psoriasis
* Deficiency of the interleukin-36 receptor antagonist
* DITRA
* Generalized pustular psoriasis of von Zumbusch
* GPP
* Von Zumbusch psoriasis

---

**Generalized Pustular Psoriasis**

**What is Generalized Pustular Psoriasis?**

Generalized pustular psoriasis (GPP) is a severe autoinflammatory phenotype of generalized pustular psoriasis. It is characterized by widespread pustules, fever, and other systemic symptoms.

**Causes of Generalized Pustular Psoriasis**

Research has identified several genetic mutations that can cause GPP. These include:

*   **IL36RN mutations**: Deficiencies in the interleukin-36 receptor antagonist (IL36RN) gene have been linked to GPP.
*   **CARD14 gain-of-function variants**: Certain variants of the CARD14 gene, which encodes an epidermal regulator of NF-kappaB, can lead to GPP.

**Symptoms and Diagnosis**

The symptoms of GPP can vary in severity and may include:

*   Widespread pustules
*   Fever
*   Malaise
*   Joint pain and swelling
*   Skin lesions

Diagnosis is typically made through a combination of clinical evaluation, laboratory tests, and genetic analysis.

**Treatment and Management**

Treatment for GPP typically involves a multidisciplinary approach, including:

*   **Biological therapies**: Medications that target specific molecules involved in inflammation and immune response.
*   **Corticosteroids**: To reduce inflammation and suppress the immune system.
*   **Immunosuppressive agents**: To modulate the immune response and prevent further inflammation.
*   **Supportive care**: To manage symptoms, prevent complications, and improve quality of life.

**Prognosis**

The prognosis for individuals with GPP varies depending on the underlying cause, severity of symptoms, and effectiveness of treatment. With proper management, many people with GPP can experience significant improvement in their symptoms and quality of life.

title: Genes and Gene Therapy: MedlinePlus
content:
**Genes and Gene Therapy**

Genes are the building blocks of inheritance. Passed from parent to child, they contain instructions for making proteins. If genes don't produce the right proteins or don't produce them correctly, a child can have a genetic disorder.

Gene therapy is an experimental technique that uses genes to treat or prevent disease. The most common form of gene therapy involves inserting a normal gene to replace an abnormal gene. Other approaches include:

* Swapping an abnormal gene for a normal one
* Repairing an abnormal gene
* Altering the degree to which a gene is turned on or off

Although there is much hope for gene therapy, it is still experimental.

title: Genes: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Genes**

A gene is a short piece of DNA. Genes tell the body how to build specific proteins. There are about 20,000 genes in each cell of the human body. Together, they make up the blueprint for the human body and how it works.

*   A person's genetic makeup is called a genotype.

**Information**

Genes are made of DNA. Strands of DNA make up part of your chromosomes. Chromosomes have matching strands of DNA that make specific genes. Except for the sex chromosomes (X and Y), chromosomes are paired so there are 2 genes, 1 on each chromosome. The gene occurs in the same position on each chromosome.

Genetic traits, such as eye color, are dominant or recessive:

*   Dominant traits are controlled by 1 gene in the pair of chromosomes.
*   Recessive traits need both genes in the gene pair to work together.

Many personal characteristics, such as height, are determined by more than 1 gene. However, some diseases, such as sickle cell anemia, can be caused by a change in a single gene.

**References**

Biesecker LG. Clinical genomics-genome structure and variation. In: Goldman L, Schafer AI, eds. Goldman-Cecil Medicine. 26th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2020:chap 36.

Taber's Cyclopedic Medical Dictionary. 24th ed. Gene. Philadelphia, PA: F.A. Davis Company; 2021. www.tabers.com/tabersonline/view/Tabers-Dictionary/729952/all/gene. Accessed June 13, 2023.

**Review Date**

4/27/2023

**Updated by**

Linda J. Vorvick, MD, Clinical Professor, Department of Family Medicine, UW Medicine, School of Medicine, University of Washington, Seattle, WA. Also reviewed by David C. Dugdale, MD, Medical Director, Brenda Conaway, Editorial Director, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.

**Learn how to cite this page**

*   [Instructions on citing this page](link to citation instructions)

---

**Genes**

\n\n

**What is a gene?**

A gene is a unit of heredity that carries information from one generation to the next. It's like a blueprint for making proteins, which are essential for various bodily functions.

\n\n

**How do genes work?**

Genes are made up of DNA, which is coiled into chromosomes. Each chromosome contains many genes, and each gene has a specific function. When a gene is expressed, it provides instructions for making a particular protein.

\n\n

**What's the difference between a gene and a chromosome?**

A chromosome is a long molecule of DNA that carries multiple genes. A gene, on the other hand, is a specific unit of heredity that contains information for making a particular protein. Think of a chromosome as a bookshelf and a gene as a single book on that shelf.

\n\n

**How do genes relate to diseases?**

Genes can play a role in certain diseases when they contain mutations or abnormalities that affect their function. For example, some genetic disorders are caused by faulty genes that disrupt normal bodily processes.

\n\n

**What's gene therapy?**

Gene therapy is a medical treatment that aims to fix or replace faulty genes responsible for genetic disorders. By introducing healthy copies of the gene into cells, researchers hope to restore normal function and alleviate symptoms associated with these conditions.

\n\n

**Related topics:**

* Genes and Gene Therapy
* Chromosomes and DNA

title: Genetic Brain Disorders | MedlinePlus
content:
**Genetic Brain Disorders**

A genetic brain disorder is caused by a variation or a mutation in a gene. A variation is a different form of a gene. A mutation is a change in a gene. Genetic brain disorders affect the development and function of the brain.

Some genetic brain disorders are due to random gene mutations or mutations caused by environmental exposure, such as cigarette smoke. Other disorders are inherited, which means that a mutated gene or group of genes is passed down through a family. They can also be due to a combination of both genetic changes and other outside factors.

**Examples of Genetic Brain Disorders**

* Leukodystrophies
* Phenylketonuria
* Tay-Sachs disease
* Wilson disease

Many people with genetic brain disorders fail to produce enough of certain proteins that influence brain development and function. These brain disorders can cause serious problems that affect the nervous system. Some have treatments to control symptoms. Some are life-threatening.

A genetic brain disorder is caused by a variation or a mutation in a gene. A variation is a different form of a gene. A mutation is a change in a gene. Genetic brain disorders affect the development and function of the brain.

Some genetic brain disorders are due to random gene mutations or mutations caused by environmental exposure, such as cigarette smoke. Other disorders are inherited, which means that a mutated gene or group of genes is passed down through a family. **Genetic Brain Disorders**

* **tics**
* **Childhood myocerebrohepatopathy spectrum**: A rare genetic disorder characterized by muscle weakness, seizures, and liver disease.
* **Citrullinemia**: A metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme argininosuccinate lyase, leading to an accumulation of citrulline in the blood.
* **Coats plus syndrome**: A rare genetic disorder characterized by vascular malformations, developmental delays, and seizures.
* **Combined malonic and methylmalonic aciduria**: A metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme succinyl-CoA:3-ketoacid CoA transferase, leading to an accumulation of malonic and methylmalonic acids in the blood.
* **Dentatorubral-pallidoluysian atrophy**: A rare genetic disorder characterized by progressive degeneration of the brain, leading to symptoms such as chorea, dystonia, and cognitive decline.
* **Deoxyguanosine kinase deficiency**: A rare genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme deoxyguanosine kinase, leading to an accumulation of deoxyguanosine in the blood.
* **Dihydrolipoamide dehydrogenase deficiency**: A metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme dihydrolipoamide dehydrogenase, leading to an accumulation of lipoic acid in the blood.
* **Dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase deficiency**: A rare genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase, leading to an accumulation of 5-fluorouracil in the blood.
* **Ethylmalonic encephalopathy**: A rare genetic disorder characterized by seizures, developmental delays, and an accumulation of ethylmalonic acid in the blood.
* **Fabry disease**: A genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme alpha-GAL A, leading to an accumulation of globotriaosylceramide in the blood.
* **Fragile X-associated tremor/ataxia syndrome**: A rare genetic disorder characterized by tremors, ataxia, and cognitive decline.
* **Fucosidosis**: A metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme alpha-L-fucosidase, leading to an accumulation of fucose in the blood.
* **Fumarase deficiency**: A rare genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme fumarase, leading to an accumulation of fumarate in the blood.
* **GABA-transaminase deficiency**: A metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme GABA-transaminase, leading to an accumulation of GABA in the blood.
* **Galactosemia**: A genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase, leading to an accumulation of galactose in the blood.
* **GLUT1 deficiency syndrome**: A rare genetic disorder characterized by seizures, developmental delays, and an inability to transport glucose across the blood-brain barrier.
* **Glutamate formiminotransferase deficiency**: A metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glutamate formiminotransferase, leading to an accumulation of formiminoglutamate in the blood.
* **Glutaric acidemia type I**: A genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glutaryl-CoA dehydrogenase, leading to an accumulation of glutarate in the blood.
* **Glutathione synthetase deficiency**: A metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glutathione synthetase, leading to an accumulation of glutathione in the blood.
* **GM1 gangliosidosis**: A genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme beta-galactosidase, leading to an accumulation of GM1 ganglioside in the brain.
* **GRIN2B-related neurodevelopmental disorder**: A rare genetic disorder characterized by seizures, developmental delays, and cognitive decline.
* **Guanidinoacetate methyltransferase deficiency**: A metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme guanidinoacetate methyltransferase, leading to an accumulation of guanidinoacetate in the blood.

**Genetic Brain Disorders**

\n\n

**Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome**
------------------------

*   A rare genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT)
*   Characterized by excessive uric acid production, leading to kidney stones and joint problems
*   Also associated with self-mutilation, aggression, and intellectual disability

\n\n

**Maple Syrup Urine Disease**
---------------------------

*   A metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme complex that breaks down amino acids
*   Characterized by a distinctive sweet odor in urine, which resembles maple syrup
*   Can lead to seizures, developmental delays, and muscle weakness if left untreated

\n\n

**Menkes Disease**
-------------------

*   A genetic disorder affecting copper metabolism, leading to impaired brain development and function
*   Characterized by curly hair, poor wound healing, and seizures
*   Typically fatal within the first few years of life if not treated with copper supplements

\n\n

**Neuronal Ceroid Lipofuscinoses (NCL)**
--------------------------------------

*   A group of rare genetic disorders affecting lysosomal function and leading to progressive brain damage
*   Characterized by seizures, vision loss, and cognitive decline
*   Can be caused by mutations in various genes, including CLN3 and TPP1

\n\n

**Niemann-Pick Disease**
------------------------

*   A group of genetic disorders affecting sphingomyelin metabolism, leading to progressive brain damage and dysfunction
*   Characterized by seizures, developmental delays, and respiratory problems
*   Can be caused by mutations in the SMPD1 gene or other related genes

\n\n

**Related Health Topics**

*   **Carbohydrate Metabolism Disorders**: disorders affecting glucose metabolism and energy production
*   **Cerebellar Disorders**: disorders affecting the cerebellum, responsible for balance and coordination
*   **Genetic Disorders**: a broad category of disorders caused by genetic mutations or chromosomal abnormalities
*   **Genetic Testing**: diagnostic tests used to identify genetic mutations or chromosomal abnormalities
*   **Leukodystrophies**: a group of rare genetic disorders affecting myelin production and function
*   **Lipid Metabolism Disorders**: disorders affecting the breakdown and utilization of lipids
*   **Metabolic Disorders**: disorders affecting energy production, glucose metabolism, or other metabolic processes
*   **Mitochondrial Diseases**: disorders affecting mitochondrial function and energy production
*   **Phenylketonuria**: a genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase
*   **Tay-Sachs Disease**: a rare genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase A
*   **Wilson Disease**: a genetic disorder affecting copper metabolism and leading to impaired brain development and function

\n\n

The primary NIH organization for research on Genetic Brain Disorders is the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke.

title: Genetic Consultation: MedlinePlus Genetics
content:
**Genetic Consultation**

You're considering a genetic consultation, but what exactly is it? A genetic consultation is a meeting with a genetics professional to discuss your family's medical history and how it might relate to your own health.

**Why Might Someone Have a Genetic Consultation?**

Maybe you're trying to understand why you or a family member has a certain condition. Perhaps you want to know if there's a genetic component to a disease that runs in your family. Whatever the reason, a genetic consultation can provide valuable insights and help you make informed decisions about your health.

**What Happens During a Genetic Consultation?**

During a genetic consultation, you'll typically meet with a genetics professional who will ask you questions about your family's medical history. They may also perform physical exams or order tests to help identify any potential genetic issues. The goal is to provide you with accurate information and support so you can make the best choices for your health.

**How Can I Find a Genetics Professional in My Area?**

To find a genetics professional near you, start by asking your primary care physician for recommendations. You can also search online or check with your local medical society for a list of qualified genetics professionals in your area.

**What is the Prognosis of a Genetic Condition?**

The prognosis of a genetic condition depends on various factors, including the specific condition, its severity, and how it's treated. A genetic consultation can help you understand the potential outcomes and develop a plan to manage the condition effectively.

**How Are Genetic Conditions Diagnosed?**

Genetic conditions are typically diagnosed through a combination of family history, physical exams, and genetic testing. The type and extent of testing will depend on the suspected condition and your individual circumstances.

**How Are Genetic Conditions Treated or Managed?**

Treatment and management of genetic conditions vary widely depending on the specific condition and its severity. A genetic consultation can help you understand the available options and develop a personalized plan to manage the condition effectively.

title: Genetic Counseling: MedlinePlus
content:
**Genetic Counseling**

Genetic counseling provides information and support to people who have, or may be at risk for, genetic disorders.

**Why Seek Genetic Counseling?**

You may consider seeking genetic counseling if you:

* Have a personal or family history of a genetic condition or birth defect
* Are pregnant or planning to be pregnant after age 35
* Already have a child with a genetic disorder or birth defect
* Have had two or more pregnancy losses or a baby who died
* Have had ultrasound or screening tests that suggest a possible problem

**Resources**

* Frequently Asked Questions about Genetic Counseling (National Human Genome Research Institute)
* Genetic Counseling (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention)
* Genetic Counseling (March of Dimes Foundation)
* Also in Spanish
* Genetic Counseling (For Parents) (Nemours Foundation)
* Also in Spanish
* Making Sense of Your Genes: A Guide to Genetic Counseling (Genetic Alliance)

**Related Issues**

* About Genetic Counselors (National Society of Genetic Counselors)
* Also in Spanish
* Genetics: MedlinePlus Genetics (National Library of Medicine)
* Also in Spanish

**Specifics**

* Genetic Counseling for Congenital Heart Defects (American Heart Association)
* Genetic Counseling for Hereditary Breast and Ovarian Cancer (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention)
* Understanding Genetic Testing for Cancer Risk (American Cancer Society)
* Also in Spanish

---

**Genetic Counseling**

\n\n

**What Is Genetic Counseling?**

Genetic counseling is a process where a genetic counselor helps individuals understand the risks of inherited disorders in their families. It involves discussing family medical histories, explaining the risks associated with certain genetic conditions, and providing guidance on testing options.

\n\n

* **Find a Genetic Counselor**: The National Society of Genetic Counselors provides a directory to find a genetic counselor near you.
* **Talking Glossary of Genetic Terms**: The National Human Genome Research Institute offers a glossary of genetic terms to help individuals understand complex genetic concepts.

\n\n

**Prenatal Genetic Counseling**

Prenatal genetic counseling involves discussing the risks of inherited disorders during pregnancy. A genetic counselor will typically:

* Review the family medical history
* Explain the risks associated with certain genetic conditions
* Discuss testing options, such as amniocentesis or chorionic villus sampling (CVS)
* Provide guidance on making informed decisions about prenatal testing

\n\n

**Genetic Disorders and Testing**

Some common genetic disorders that may be discussed during prenatal genetic counseling include:

* **Birth Defects**: Genetic conditions that affect the development of an embryo or fetus
* **Family History**: A review of the family medical history to identify potential genetic risks
* **Genetic Disorders**: Inherited conditions that can affect various aspects of health, such as physical characteristics, cognitive function, or organ function
* **Genetic Testing**: Laboratory tests used to detect genetic disorders in individuals or families

\n\n

**Resources**

For more information on genetic counseling and related topics, consider the following resources:

* **National Human Genome Research Institute**: A leading organization for research on genetic counseling and related topics
* **March of Dimes Foundation**: A non-profit organization providing education and support on prenatal health and genetic disorders
* **American Academy of Pediatrics**: A professional organization offering guidance on pediatric genetic care

\n\n

**Disclaimer**

MedlinePlus links to health information from the National Institutes of Health and other federal government agencies. MedlinePlus also links to health information from non-government Web sites. See our disclaimer about external links and our quality guidelines.

title: Genetic Disorders: MedlinePlus
content:
**Genetic Disorders**

**Basics**

* Genes are the building blocks of heredity.
* They are passed from parent to child.
* They hold DNA, the instructions for making proteins.
* Proteins do most of the work in cells.

**Summary**

* A genetic disorder is a medical condition caused by a mutation in one or more genes.
* You can inherit a gene mutation from one or both parents.
* A mutation can also happen during your lifetime.

**Start Here**

**Genetic Disorders**

There are mutations in two or more genes. Often your lifestyle and environment also play a role. Colon cancer is an example.

**Genetic Tests**

Genetic tests on blood and other tissue can identify genetic disorders.

**What Are Genes?**

NIH: National Library of Medicine
Genes are the building blocks of heredity. They are passed from parent to child. They hold DNA, the instructions for making proteins. Proteins do most of the work in cells. They move molecules from one place to another, build structures, break down toxins, and do many other maintenance jobs.

**What Happens When There's a Mutation?**

Sometimes there is a mutation, a change in a gene or genes. The mutation changes the gene's instructions for making a protein, so the protein does not work properly or is missing entirely. This can cause a medical condition called a genetic disorder.

**How Do You Inherit a Gene Mutation?**

You can inherit a gene mutation from one or both parents. A mutation can also happen during your lifetime.

**Types of Genetic Disorders**

There are three types of genetic disorders:

*   **Inherited**: Passed down from parents
*   **Acquired**: Happen during a person's lifetime
*   **Mixed**: Combination of inherited and acquired factors
